awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Celebrating the successes and identifying the obstacles faced by innovative and entrepreneurial underrepresented women of color
awd_abstract_narration:
This EAGER award conducts exploratory research on the successes and obstacles faced by innovative and entrepreneurial women of color in STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics).  Situated within the intersectionality framework, this research will be conducted via in-depth interviews and focus groups with Underrepresented Women of Color (URWOC) innovators and entrepreneurs. This research defines Women of Color as those women who identify as African-American/Black, Latinx/Hispanic/Chicana, and Indigenous/Native Alaskan/ Native Hawaiian to better understand: (1) the background of URWOC founders and how they became interested in starting a STEM venture; 2) the strategies that URWOC owner/founders employed to start and persist in their ventures/innovations, choose to license, or sell their ventures/innovations; 3) similarities and differences in intersectionality across URWOC groups who are engaged in STEM innovation and entrepreneurship (I&E); 4) the unique experiences and challenges that URWOC endure in their I&E endeavors and 5) how to increase the number of URWOC in I&E with a focus on providing assistance to national initiatives aimed at diversifying underrepresented groups in I&E. This research will support the creation of theoretically robust yet practical frameworks for understanding the experiences of URWOC innovators and entrepreneurs in STEM.  In turn, these insights will be used to integrate research with practice via the creation of outcomes that have the potential to engage a variety of stakeholders in co-creating solutions focused on increasing the number of URWOC in STEM Innovation & Entrepreneurship (I&E).

This research project fills an important gap in synthesizing the literature on intersectionality and entrepreneurship and innovation in STEM for URWOCs and documenting the historical changes of the composition of URWOC in STEM I&E across the nation.  Findings will inform and connect to more robust investigations of how key factors impact URWOC who are engaging in unique experiences that enable their success and enhance their ability to overcome typical issues of race, class, and gender oppression for URWOC in STEM I&E.  Research findings will provide critical information for use by STEM education and STEM entrepreneurship researchers, stakeholders, and leadership n STEM in policy formation, assessment of the progress of diversity initiatives toward building a vibrant and robust community of URWOC.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the NSF-funded project outlined in this final report were to explore the successes and obstacles faced by women of color in STEM fields who are involved in entrepreneurship, specifically in the areas of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The project aimed to achieve these goals through various research activities.

One of the key accomplishments of the project was the hiring of undergraduate student workers who were trained to support the research by creating annotated bibliographies of published literature related to STEM entrepreneurship, entrepreneurs of color, and women founders in STEM. This literature review served as a foundation for the project's understanding of the experiences of Black, Native American/Indigenous, and Latinx women founders.

Additionally, the project involved the virtual convening of Advisory Board Members who provided critical feedback on interview protocols and survey instruments. In addition to conducting semi-sctructured interviews with over 50 women STEM founders, the project team designed and launched two novel survey instruments, one targeting nascent women founders and the other targeting existing women founders in STEM. These surveys aimed to quantitatively assess the obstacles and opportunities faced by BIPOC women entrepreneurs.

The project also made progress in drafting a comprehensive literature review on BIPOC women STEM founders, synthesizing existing research and providing insights into the current state of these women entrepreneurs and innovators. This literature review serves as a valuable resource for understanding the unique experiences, resilience, and persistence of BIPOC women in STEM entrepreneurship.

Significant results were obtained from the preliminary quantitative analysis. A multiple linear regression analysis was conducted to predict the likelihood of students intending to pursue entrepreneurship. The results indicated that psychosocial variables, health-related constructs, and attendance at Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs) significantly influenced the participants' career plans. Racial activism and minority status stress emerged as significant predictors of the likelihood to pursue entrepreneurship. 

The report also highlighted preliminary qualitative insights gathered from 12 out of 25 interview participants. These insights provided valuable information about the motivations, challenges, preparation, and legacy aspirations of women of color in STEM entrepreneurship. Participants expressed a desire for independence and a greater control over their professional careers as a primary motivation for pursuing entrepreneurship. High-scoring participants on the racial activism scale emphasized the importance of making a positive impact on their communities through entrepreneurship. Funding, race-based impediments, and resource identification were identified as major challenges. The participants also recognized the value of their technical backgrounds and academic preparation in supporting their entrepreneurial ventures. For those high-scoring on racial activism, there was a collective element in their vision for their legacy, focusing on group empowerment for people of color.

Overall, this NSF-funded project made significant progress towards its goals. The research activities conducted, including literature reviews, interviews, and surveys, provided valuable insights into the experiences, motivations, challenges, and aspirations of women of color in STEM entrepreneurship. The findings shed light on the significance of racial activism and minority status stress as predictors of entrepreneurial intent. The outcomes of this project have the potential to inform higher education institutions and social enterprises, encouraging them to support and investigate the objectives and motivations of racially minoritized nascent entrepreneurs.

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2023
Modified by: Thema Monroe-White
